Articles.Content: I'm planning a duna mission using a large mothership, and with all landers attached the total part count is 330. Assuming I play in 64 bit and have a reasonably good computer, how much lag will this likely cause me?

Try it and find out!

It might be more useful if you knew your CPU speed, number of CPU cores, and how much RAM you have. Those are numbers that will determine your lag.

3 minutes ago, dire said:

Try it and find out!

It might be more useful if you knew your CPU speed, number of CPU cores, and how much RAM you have. Those are numbers that will determine your lag.

Ah, okay. Here you go:

CPU speed: 2.00 GHz max (Core M, Throttleable)

2 cores

8 GB of ram
Probably very noticeably laggy. Your CPU is going to be very busy.

1 hour ago, dire said:

Probably very noticeably laggy. Your CPU is going to be very busy.

Darn. I may be able to cut down a bit...

There are factors beyond simple part count too.  Open docking ports are apparently awful for lag (I'm still coming up with a test case to conclusively document this) - which can be mitigated with three different kinds of shielded or retracting ports, or keeping extra ports covered with heatshields etc until needed.  Onboard spotlights cause slowdowns when activated - keep count and keep it minimal.  

As far as reducing lag / latency / stutter / etc - consider the tree structure of KSP parts.  Imagine a ship constructed around a large central fuel tank.  If you use wing segments coming off the tank, more tanks on the wingtips, engines and landing legs on the wingtip tanks - those landing legs are three tree branches from the core of the ship, and six to the other legs.  Or you could use a mod that provides NoOffsetLimit (like RCSBuildAid), mount everything to the central tank, and offset parts to where you'd like them to be visually.  Maximum two branches to compute when (for instance) you land on the surface a little too hard.  It stands to reason that this should reduce the number of physics interactions KSP has to compute.  I haven't proven this conclusively, but it seems true in some tests I've tried.

Thoughts?

Edited August 17, 2016 by fourfa

On 8/16/2016 at 11:25 PM, fourfa said:

There are factors beyond simple part count too.  Open docking ports are apparently awful for lag (I'm still coming up with a test case to conclusively document this) - which can be mitigated with three different kinds of shielded or retracting ports, or keeping extra ports covered with heatshields etc until needed.  Onboard spotlights cause slowdowns when activated - keep count and keep it minimal.  

That I can do rather easily. I have a total of 12 docking ports, 8 of which are used for construction. I'll just make sure to keep the upper stages attached to each segment until it's ready to be attached. I can also try replacing some of the docking ports used for ship-to-ship docking with their shielded equivalents.

On 8/16/2016 at 11:25 PM, fourfa said:

As far as reducing lag / latency / stutter / etc - consider the tree structure of KSP parts.  Imagine a ship constructed around a large central fuel tank.  If you use wing segments coming off the tank, more tanks on the wingtips, engines and landing legs on the wingtip tanks - those landing legs are three tree branches from the core of the ship, and six to the other legs.  Or you could use a mod that provides NoOffsetLimit (like RCSBuildAid), mount everything to the central tank, and offset parts to where you'd like them to be visually.  Maximum two branches to compute when (for instance) you land on the surface a little too hard.  It stands to reason that this should reduce the number of physics interactions KSP has to compute.  I haven't proven this conclusively, but it seems true in some tests I've tried.

I'm unfortunately long past that now, as the ship is built around a long spine of trusses. However, I don't have any long outriggers, pylons, booms, etc., most of the parts are attached directly to the spine.

On 8/16/2016 at 11:25 PM, fourfa said:

Thoughts?

Thanks for the help! You should start a separate thread for your theory, if it proves to be true it could help a lot of people with lag.
